questions.text: You are working as an intern in the casualty department where you received a 60-year-old patient in cardiac arrest. The sequence of management in cardiac arrest is:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

C → A → B The conventional sequence of A→ B→ C has been changed to C → A → B which means 30 compressions over a period of 18-20 seconds to be followed by airway and breathing.

Extraedge:

The reason for this change is that studies have proven that there is enough oxygen present in the blood, which by giving 30 initial compressions can be pushed to vital structures like the brain and heart. Moreover, during this time airway equipment also becomes ready.

questions.text: Not done in the image below for Airway management :
questions.correct_answer: B. In line cervical spine stabilization
questions.explanation:
Solution:

In line cervical spine stabilization In line management of the cervical spine is done when the airway is managed in a suspected cervical spine injury patient. Cervical spine stabilization can be done by applying a hard collar or manually by holding the head and neck

Highyeild:

Tongue fall is the most common cause of airway obstruction. A simple maneuver (triple maneuver) which includes neck extension, chin lift and jaw thrust (i.e., pull the mandible anteriorly) can prevent the tongue fall. The more definitive management to prevent tongue fall is insertion of airway or intubation.

Extraedge:

All patients with a head injury should be considered to be suffering from cervical spine injury until proved otherwise Since the removal of a hard collar is often required for intubation, manual stabilization is preferred over collar stabilization.

questions.text: The following four items consist of two statements, one labeled the ‘Assertion A’ and the other labeled the ‘Reason R’. You are to examine these two statements carefully and decide if the Assertion (A) and the Reason (R) are individually true and if so, whether the Reason is a correct explanation of the Assertion. Select your answers to these items using the codes given below the mark your answer sheet accordingly: Assertion – (A): For airway management flexion of the neck is required Reason – (R): Jaw thrust prevents the tongue from falling back on the posterior pharyngeal wall

options.label: A
options.text: Both Assertion and Reasons are independently true/correct statements and the Reason is the true/correct explanation for the Assertion

options.label: B
options.text: Both Assertion and Reasons are independently true /correct statements, but the Reason is not the true/correct explanation for the Assertion

options.label: C
options.text: The assertion is independently a true/correct statement, but the Reasons is independently a false/incorrect statement

options.label: D
options.text: The assertion is independently a false/incorrect statement, but the Reasons is independently a true/correct statement

questions.correct_answer: D. The assertion is independently a false/incorrect statement, but the Reasons is independently a true/correct statement
questions.explanation:
Solution:

The assertion is independently a false/incorrect statement, but the Reasons is independently a true/correct statement A simple maneuver (triple maneuver) applied to prevent tongue fall includes neck extension, chin lift, and jaw thrust (i.e., pull the mandible anteriorly). Therefore, Assertion is wrong while reason is the correct statement

questions.text: Not a component of basic life support:

options.label: B
options.text: Defibrillation with an automatic external defibrillator

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Intubation Airway management by intubation, Laryngeal mask airway or tracheostomy is part of advanced life support while airway management by mouth-to-mouth or bag and mask ventilation is part of basic life support.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option B- Defibrillation by manual defibrillators is a part of advanced life support as it can only be managed by medical professionals while automatic defibrillators can be handled by a layman therefore, considered a part of basic life support. In basic life support airway is managed by manual method, breathing by bag and mask, and cardiac function by cardiac massage. In advance life supports airway by instruments, breathing by intubation, and cardiac function by cardiac massage.

questions.text: On your morning walk in the park, you noticed an unconscious man lying on the road. Which of the following options indicates the best next steps?

options.label: A
options.text: Check carotid pulse, start CPR and call for help, defibrillate if no pulse

options.label: B
options.text: Call for help, check pulse, do CPR, Defibrillate if no pulse

options.label: C
options.text: Observe and wait till the ambulance arrives

options.label: D
options.text: Defibrillate, check pulse and do CPR

questions.correct_answer: B. Call for help, check pulse, do CPR, Defibrillate if no pulse
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Call for help, check pulse, do CPR, Defibrillate if no pulse ALGORITHM FOR CPR

questions.text: When is the recommended position used?

options.label: B
options.text: Pulse and respiration both are abnormal

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Pulse and respiration normal This is the left lateral position which is the aspiration prevention position. The patient should be nursed in the left lateral position if on assessment it is found that the patient is only unconscious with a normal pulse and breathing, which means, the patient does not require CPR.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Options A, B, and C- If either breathing is absent or pulse is absent or both are absent then the patient requires CPR which is done in the supine position.

questions.text: A 5-year-old patient presented to an accident and emergency in cardiorespiratory arrest. True statement regarding basic life support steps in this child:

options.label: A
options.text: First step is to start CPR

options.label: B
options.text: After assessing the airway, breathing, and circulation the next step is to call for emergency medical services

options.label: C
options.text: After assessing the airway, breathing, and circulation, the next step is 5 cycles of CPR

options.label: D
options.text: After assessing the airway, breathing, and circulation, the next step is defibrillation

questions.correct_answer: C. After assessing the airway, breathing, and circulation, the next step is 5 cycles of CPR
questions.explanation:
Solution:

After assessing the airway, breathing, and circulation, the next step is 5 cycles of CPR In children with unwitnessed cardiac arrest, the cause should be considered asystole until proven otherwise, so resuscitators should give 5 cycles of CPR before calling for emergency medical services starting with chest compression followed by airway and breathing management.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option A- CPR should be started only after assessment of consciousness, circulation, and breathing Option B- In unwitnessed (unmonitored) cardiac arrest the cause of cardiac arrest in an adult should be considered as ventricular fibrillation until proved otherwise therefore after assessing responsiveness, the emergency medical response team should be called so that the patient can be defibrillated at the earliest. Option D- Defibrillation is done only if ventricular fibrillation is proven on the monitor

questions.text: A 5-year-old child is rushed to casualty and reportedly electrocuted while playing in the park. The child is apneic and ventilated with a bag and mask. Which one of the following will be the next step:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Check pulses In the clinical scenario mentioned here, the patient ventilation has already been started with a bag and mask. Therefore, the next step is to assess circulation by checking the carotid pulse. If the pulse is not palpable, immediately start the cardiac massage and then replace bag and mask ventilation with ventilation with an endotracheal tube. However, if the pulses are present then the next step will be intubation.

questions.text: Oxygen delivered by mouth-to-mouth respiration:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

16% As per new guidelines mouth-to-mouth breathing is only recommended for trained rescuers as it requires technical training, just delivers 16% oxygen, and deter the rescuer to perform another important function of cardiac massage. Therefore, now for the common man CPR means “hand only” i.e., just cardiac massage.

questions.text: While providing CPR to an adult patient, who had suddenly collapsed on the road, what ratio of chest compressions to rescue breaths would you provide if there were 2 rescuers?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

30:2 For an adult patient, the ratio of cardiac compression to breathing during basic life support (i.e., when breathing is accomplished with a bag and mask) is 30:2 irrespective of no. of resuscitators. Once the breathing is accomplished with an advanced method like intubation then there are no ratios, compression has to be carried at a rate of 100-120 /min. and breathing at a rate of 10/min without any synchronization between compression and breathing.

Extraedge:

For pediatric patients without an advanced airway, the ratio is 30:2 for a single resuscitator and 15:2 for 2 resuscitators. Once the child is intubated, the compression is continued at a rate of 100-120/minute, and breathing at a rate of 20-30 breaths/minute without any synchronization between compression and breathing.

questions.text: Regarding CPR, False statement:

options.label: A
options.text: Can be given irrespective of rib fracture

options.label: B
options.text: Adult chest compression and ventilation ratio is 30:2 with 2 rescuers

options.label: D
options.text: AED if available, give compressions and shock every 3 minutes

questions.correct_answer: D. AED if available, give compressions and shock every 3 minutes
questions.explanation:
Solution:

AED if available, give compressions and shock every 3 minutes True, Chest compression is given at the lower one-third of the sternum True, chest compression and ventilation ratio for adults, irrespective of no. of rescuers is 30:2 True – compression rate is 100-120/minute False- Check rhythm after 2 minutes and give shock only if the rhythm is shockable

questions.text: A 65-year-old male patient is undergoing CPR for cardiac arrest due to a massive MI. All of the following statements related to his CPR are true except:

options.label: A
options.text: Sternum should be depressed by 2 inches

options.label: B
options.text: Effective cardiac massage produces only one third of the normal cardiac output

options.label: C
options.text: End-tidal CO2 < 10 mmHg indicates unsuccessful CPR

options.label: D
options.text: Mean arterial pressure < 20 mmHg indicates unsuccessful CPR

questions.correct_answer: D. Mean arterial pressure < 20 mmHg indicates unsuccessful CPR
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Mean arterial pressure < 20 mmHg indicates unsuccessful CPR As coronary filling occurs during diastole therefore diastolic blood pressure is taken as a marker to check the success of CPR. Diastolic blood pressure (measured intra arterially) < 20 mmHg indicates unsuccessful CPR.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option A- In adults and children, the sternum should be depressed by at least one-third of the AP diameter {2 inches (5 cm)} but should not be more than 2.4 inches. In infants, it should be depressed by 1.5 inches. Option B- Successful cardiac massage produces only produce 25-30% of normal cardiac output therefore, restoration of normal rhythm and spontaneous circulation should be achieved as early as possible Option C- A successful cardiac massage should be able to produce ETCO2 > 20 mmHg. ETCO2 between 10-20 mmHg indicates that CPR requires improvement while ETCO2 < 10 indicates completely unsuccessful CPR.

Extraedge:

Other than Diastolic blood pressure and ETCO2, mixed venous oxygen saturation is also used to see the success of CPR. Mixed venous oxygen saturation < 30% indicates unsuccessful CPR.

questions.text: A young patient following RTA reported to the accident and emergency department. The pulses were not palpable however the monitor recorded cardiac activity with severe bradycardia. All of the following statements are true regarding this clinical situation except:

options.label: A
options.text: The most common cause of this scenario is hypovolemia

options.label: C
options.text: The first step should be to inject atropine

options.label: D
options.text: Adrenaline is the drug of choice for this situation

questions.correct_answer: C. The first step should be to inject atropine
questions.explanation:
Solution:

The first step should be to inject atropine The diagnosis of this patient is Pulse electrical activity (PEA) {previously called Electromechanical dissociation}. Atropine is no longer recommended for non-shockable rhythms i.e., pulseless electrical activity and asystole.

Highyeild:

Pulseless electrical activity is a condition in which pulses are not palpable; however, the heart shows some activity (which may be even sinus rhythm) other than ventricular fibrillation and ventricular tachycardia. The causes of PEA have been divided into 5H and 5 T 5H Hypovolemia Hypokalemia/ Hyperkalemia Hypothermia Hypoxia Hydrogen ion (acidosis) 5T Tension Pneumothorax Tamponade Thrombosis Tablets (drug overdoses)/ toxins Trauma

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option A- A most common cause of Pulseless electrical activity is hypovolemia Option B- Pulseless electrical activity is among one of the 3 rhythms seen in cardiac arrest (the other two are ventricular fibrillation and asystole). Therefore, management is immediate CPR starting with the cardiac massage. Option D- The only recommended drug for non-shockable rhythm is adrenaline which should be repeated after every 2-3 minutes.

questions.text: What is not done in the given image below?

options.label: A
options.text: Intraosseous cannulation for giving IV fluids

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Bone marrow aspiration This is not the bone marrow aspiration procedure

Highyeild:

The intraosseous route is an emergency route that was previously recommended for children less than 6 years of age but now can be used at any age, anything including fluids can be given and is preferred over the endotracheal route. A large bore needle is inserted just below the tibial tuberosity and the drug/fluid is injected directly into the medullary cavity. The rate of absorption of the drug is almost equal to the intravascular route.

questions.text: Adrenaline is a very commonly used drug during CPR. Which of the following statements regarding adrenaline are true: Endotracheal dose is 2.5 times of IV dose Intracardiac adrenaline is contraindicated Increases systolic and diastolic pressure Concentration through the intraosseous route is 1: 10,000 Select the correct answer from the below code:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

1, 2, and 4 are correct The endotracheal dose is 2.5 times of IV dose and the drug is to be diluted with 10 ml of saline in adults and 5 ml in children. Intracardiac adrenaline is no better in effectiveness than IV, Intraosseous, or endotracheal. Moreover, it can cause significant myocardial damage. Therefore, present-day CPR does not advocate the use of intracardiac adrenaline. In past, it used to be given in 4th intercostal space at the left sternal border Adrenaline stimulates beta receptors. It increases the stroke volume of the Systolic pressure rises but diastolic pressure falls. Vasoconstriction in vital areas is less as compared to non-vital areas leading to the diversion of blood from non-vital (skin, splanchnic) to vital structures (brain and heart).On lower doses it causes tachycardia but on higher doses, there is reflex bradycardia because of intense vasoconstriction. The concentration of adrenaline in CPR for all three recommended routes {IV, IO, ET} is 1:10,000 except endotracheal concentration for children which is 1:1000.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs are recommended in cardiac arrest caused by shockable rhythms? Magnesium sulfate Adrenaline Sodium bicarbonate Amiodarone Select the correct answer from the below code:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

1, 2, and 4 are correct Shockable rhythms include ventricular fibrillation, pulseless ventricular tachycardia, and polymorphic ventricular tachycardia. Patients with polymorphic ventricular tachycardia may require magnesium sulfate if not responding to defibrillation and adrenaline The first shock given for the treatment of shockable rhythms is a plain shock. 2 nd and 3 rd shocks are given after injecting adrenaline Use of sodium bicarbonate without blood gas analysis is not recommended because sodium bicarbonate produces CO2 which by increasing ICT can worsen the neuronal injury. Secondly, sodium bicarbonate increases the solute load, difficult to be handled by an already compromised heart. Thirdly and most importantly by producing CO2 it can worsen intracellular acidosis (paradoxical acidosis) If the patient does not respond to 3 shocks and 2 doses of adrenaline, then he/she should receive amiodarone before the shock

questions.text: A 57-year-old patient who was a known case of MI was brought to a casualty with giddiness.As soon as the monitor was attached, the patient collapsed. The rhythm on the monitor was observed to be ventricular fibrillation. CPR was immediately started and it was decided to defibrillate the patient instantly. Which of the following statements is not correct regarding the defibrillation of this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: First shock with biphasic defibrillator should be 360 J

options.label: B
options.text: 2nd shock with monophasic defibrillator should be 200 J

options.label: C
options.text: After defibrillation, the next step should be to check the rhythm

questions.explanation:
Solution:

All of the above Option A- As biphasic defibrillators deliver current from two directions, energy of 150-200 J is sufficient to revert the rhythm. Based on the energy lost in the chest wall, the defibrillator automatically chooses the best energy between 150-200 J for that particular patient. Option B- First and all subsequent shocks with monophasic defibrillators should be of 360J. Option C- After defibrillation, the next step is to continue CPR for 2 min. before checking rhythm because it has been proven that even if rhythm returns to normal it takes 2 minutes for the heart to restore normal cardiac output.

questions.text: Paddle position for defibrillation:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

A The most ideal paddle position would be one over the precordium and the second posteriorly (i.e., the heart is sandwiched) but this is not possible in a supine position so 1st paddle is placed just below the right clavicle and the second at the precordium.

questions.text: Defibrillator preferred for infants:

options.label: C
options.text: Anyone depending on the clinical condition

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Manual Manual defibrillators are preferred in infants however if not available AED can be used safely. Pediatric pads should preferably be used in children less than 8 years. For more than 8 years adult pads can be used.

questions.text: True statement about the following image:

options.label: A
options.text: It is part of advanced life support

options.label: B
options.text: It only delivers a shock of 300J

options.label: C
options.text: One pad is applied over the precordium and another over the sternum

options.label: D
options.text: It’s for use of common people

questions.correct_answer: D. It’s for use of common people
questions.explanation:
Solution:

It’s for use of common people It’s an image of an automatic external defibrillator (AED). It automatically detects the rhythm and if the rhythm is shockable, it delivers the energy by itself. Since its automatic is meant for use by the public.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option A- As automatic external defibrillators can be used by the general public, they are part of basic life support. Option B- If biphasic, it delivers a shock of 150-200 J and if monophasic it will deliver a shock of 360 J. Option C- Apex pad is placed over precordium while the sternal pad is placed right infraclavicular.

Extraedge:

Automatic external defibrillators are now called public access defibrillators (PAD)

questions.text: Dose of vasopressin in present-day CPR:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

None of the above Vasopressin offered no advantage, therefore has been removed from current CPR guidelines

questions.text: The only recommended method for brain protection is hypothermia which is called Targeted temperature management (TTM). TTM by definition means:

options.label: A
options.text: Maintaining core body temperature between 32°C and 36°C for 24 hours

options.label: B
options.text: Maintaining core body temperature between 32°C and 36°C for 12 hours

options.label: C
options.text: Maintaining core body temperature between 32° C and 34° C for 12 hours

options.label: D
options.text: Maintaining core body temperature between 32° C and 34° C for 24 hours

questions.correct_answer: A. Maintaining core body temperature between 32°C and 36°C for 24 hours
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Maintaining core body temperature between 32°C and 36°C for 24 hours Often, the patient recovers after cardiac arrest however remains comatose. Such patients require brain protection. The only recommended method for brain protection is targeted temperature management (previously used to be called hypothermia. Targeted temperature measurement means maintaining the core temperature between 32°C and 36°C for 24 hours.

questions.text: For infants and children, Targeted temperature management (TTM) means:

options.label: B
options.text: Maintaining hypothermia for 2 days followed by normothermia for 3 days

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Both of the above For infants and children TTM is achieved by either maintaining 5 days of continuous normothermia (36°C-37.5°C) or 2 days of hypothermia (32°C-34°C), followed by 3 days of normothermia

questions.text: Neuro-prognostication should be done after:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

72 hours Neuro-prognostication should be done after 72 hours of attaining normothermia because after 72 hours it is possible to rule out all reversible causes of coma and enough to declare a patient brain dead. If a patient is declared brain dead, the relatives should be counseled for organ donation and the process of organ donation should be started.

questions.text: False statement regarding the following device:

options.label: A
options.text: Always preferred over manual chest compression

questions.explanation:
Solution:

None of the above This is a mechanical CPR device. They are wrapped over the patient’s chest and provide compression. In spite of providing optimal rate and an optimal depth of compression, they have not been found to improve mortality. Moreover, they are also expensive. Therefore, their use should be restricted to specific situations like limited rescuers otherwise manual compressions remain the standard of care for the management of cardiac arrest.

questions.text: A 50-year man suddenly became aphonic while having dinner and present to the emergency room with difficulty in respiration. What will be the immediate step of action?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Heimlich’s maneuver In adults and children foreign body is managed by the Heimlich maneuver. In this maneuver, the rescuer stands behind the victim and compress the abdomen 6-10 times in an upward direction.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option A- Airway obstruction due to other causes like laryngeal edema, acute epiglottitis, and laryngo-tracheobronchitis where intubation is not possible, may require tracheostomy Option C- Cricothyroidotomy is a lifesaving procedure to secure the airway if a foreign body does not get relieved by the above said measures and the patient starts desaturating. Option D- only oxygenation will not be of any help till the foreign body is removed.

Extraedge:

In infants, foreign body dislodgment is done by either chest thrust or back blows. In chest thrust, 4 blows are given on the sternum with a thrust by the heel of the hand between the shoulders. In back blows, 4 blows are given in the middle of the back. Back blows are also performed for infants if sternal thrusts do not work.

questions.text: A patient after an RTA was received in an emergency with the following cannula in the picture. What is the maximum flow rate of fluid through this cannula?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

96ml/min Flow with an 18 G cannula is approximately 100 ml/minute

Extraedge:

Gauge Color Flow (ml/min.) 14 Orange 240 16 Grey 200 18 Green 60 100 20 Pink 64 22 Blue 38 24 Yellow 22 26 Purple 14

questions.text: Which among the following are required in the Cannulation of a newborn baby? 22G Needle 24 Gauge Needle Adhesive Tape 5 ml Syringe Normal Saline Select the correct answer from the below code:

options.label: D
options.text: All of the above is correct

questions.explanation:
Solution:

2, 3, 4, and 5 is correct 22 G cannula is used in children. For newborns either a 24 or 26 G cannula is used. Adhesive plast is required for the fixation of the cannula. 5 ml of syringe and saline is required for flushing the cannula

questions.text: A 50-year-old patient with a history of Hypertension and DM developed the following rhythm with blood pressure 90/40 mm of Hg and feeble pulse what is the next step of management?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Iv adenosine This is supraventricular tachycardia. If the patient is hemodynamically stable, a vagal maneuver may be tried. If no response 6 mg IV adenosine is given. Still, if there is no response 12 mg of IV adenosine is given. Still, if no response other drugs like amiodarone may be tried. However, if the patient is hemodynamically unstable then immediate cardioversion should be done

questions.text: Match the following dilution of adrenaline and its use (Column – (A) with Column – (B): Select the correct answer from the below code:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

A-2, B-1, C-3 Dose Concentration 1. CPR: 1 mg to be repeated every 3-5 min. IV/IO/ET - 1: 10,000 ET in children- 1: 1,000 2. Anaphylaxis: 0.5-1 mg to be repeated every 3-5 minutes. IM (and S/C) – 1: 1000 IV/IO/ET - 1: 10,000 3. With local anesthetics. 1: 2,00,000 4. For producing local ischemia 1: 1,00,000
